channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Businessman Guilty of Killing and Eating Tigers
item.description: The trial took place two months after the Chinese government issued a new interpretation of an existing ban on trade in endangered species that said that eating a tiger or other protected animal would be punishable by prison.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Xiongsen Bear and Tiger Park in Guilin, which holds more than 1,300 tigers. Exemptions to China's wildlife protection law permit captive breeding of endangered species for exhibition.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The People’s Liberation Army, in Lights
item.description: The Hong Kong light and laser show this week appeared to include gigantic Chinese characters that read “People’s Liberation Army” on the side of the garrison’s waterfront headquarters, alarming many locals.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: World Briefing: Moldova: European Union Plans to Invest Millions
item.description: The European Union said it would finance projects worth about $68 million in Moldova, a former Soviet republic that is prepared to sign an association agreement with the European bloc amid protests from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Jamaica: Government Aims to Relax Marijuana Laws
item.description: Jamaica’s government on Thursday announced a major rethinking of its marijuana laws, including plans to partly decriminalize small amounts of marijuana and to allow possession for religious, scientific and medical purposes.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Compensation for Nazi Seizures Increased
item.description: A Berlin court has ordered Germany to pay the heirs of Jewish owners of a department store chain about $68 million in additional compensation for property seized by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: Troops Exchange Fire With Rwandan Soldiers
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda sent more troops to their shared border on Thursday after gunfire briefly broke out for a second day.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Greece Wars With Courts Over Ways to Slash Budget
item.description: Greek judges continue to contest the government’s attempts to cut salaries, pensions and jobs of public workers to reduce the country’s debt.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Members of the Finance Ministry’s cleaning staff clashed with the police in Athens on Thursday. Nearly 400 laid-off workers want their jobs back.

item.title: Building Nuclear Weapon Would Take Years, Not Months, Iran Says in Report
item.description: The estimate contradicts both classified assessments by the United States government and many outside experts.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry has told senators it would take Iran “about two months” to amass fuel for a nuclear weapon.

item.title: Video: The Goal Heard Round Brazil
item.description: When Neymar drove the ball into the back of the net for Brazil’s first goal, pandemonium ensued around the host country.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: As Sunni Militants Threaten Its Allies in Baghdad, Iran Weighs Options
item.description: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria fighters pose a direct threat to the pro-Iranian government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, vowing to massacre Shiites and destroy their shrines.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Tanks, of Unknown Origin, Roll Into Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine’s interior minister claimed that an armored column from Russia had crossed the border into eastern Ukraine overnight.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: An apartment building in Slovyansk, Ukraine, showed damage Thursday from weeks of fighting.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Prison Sentence Feared for Detained Rights Lawyer
item.description: The prospect of the imminent release of Pu Zhiqiang, a human rights lawyer who was detained after a meeting in Beijing to mark the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, is growing dim.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Pu Zhiqiang speaking to reporters outside Chongqing Higher People's Court in December 2012.

item.title: Choosing Rebels Over Army, Iraqis Head Home
item.description: As many as 500,000 Iraqis fled Mosul after a militant group swarmed the city, many of them Sunnis who seemed less fearful of the group than their own government.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Onur Coban/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Iraqis fled Mosul this week after a siege by Islamic extremists, with a large number taking refuge in Erbil.

item.title: The Iraqi Army Was Crumbling Long Before Its Collapse, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: American military and intelligence officials told a Senate hearing that the Iraqi military had been in decline since the last American advisers left the country in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: U.S. Scrambles to Help Iraq Fight Off Militants as Baghdad Is Threatened
item.description: The White House hurried Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: “I don’t rule out anything,” President Obama said of Iraq, speaking Thursday in the Oval Office.

item.title: Kurdish Fighters Take a Key Oil City as Militants Advance on Baghdad
item.description: As the Kurds seized Kirkuk, Sunni militants threatened to advance into the heavily Shiite south and destroy shrines there.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SUADAD AL-SALHY and RICK GLADSTONE.

item.title: Bergdahl Departs Germany for Treatment in Texas
item.description: The American prisoner of war, who was freed in exchange for Taliban detainees, will receive specialized treatment the military has designed for soldiers who have endured long periods in captivity.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Soccer and Internal Discord, on Display for World to See
item.description: Brazil reaffirmed its reputation as a powerhouse of global soccer in the opening match of the World Cup, but its widening political fissures were also on display for an international audience.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: The police detained a protester on Thursday as demonstrators angry at the cost of the World Cup tried to block a highway.

item.title: Explosion Kills 6 at Indian Plant
item.description: Twenty-nine others were injured after a blast and a gas leak damaged the Bhilai steel plant in Chhattisgarh State.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: European Court Upholds $1.44 Billion Fine Against Intel
item.description: The case, which dates back to 2000, is about a competitive edge the chip maker may no longer have. But the ruling has legal implications for other tech giants.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Intel still can appeal the case to Europe’s highest court, the European Court of Justice.

item.title: Woman Is Found Hanged in Indian State
item.description: The body of a 19-year-old woman was found hanging from a eucalyptus tree, the third similar discovery in the state of Uttar Pradesh in two weeks.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Open Source: Police Tactics Under Increased Scrutiny at World Cup
item.description: Protesters in Brazil accused the police of using excessive force against a demonstration in São Paulo on Thursday, ahead of the World Cup kickoff.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: In World Cup, Mexico Believes Anything Can Happen After Rough Road to Brazil
item.description: After cycling through 4 coaches and nearly 50 players and barely surviving qualifying, Mexico will begin the World Cup on Friday with a match in Group A against Cameroon.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW KEH
item.media:description: Mexico’s team faces Cameroon in its World Cup opener on Friday.

item.title: Ex-Leader of Ivory Coast Is Ordered to Stand Trial
item.description: The International Criminal Court said former President Laurent Gbagbo would be tried on charges of crimes against humanity in connection with violence after 2010 elections in Ivory Coast.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: U.S. Drone Hits Pakistan for 2nd Time in 12 Hours
item.description: The strikes were apparently aimed at the Haqqani network, a Taliban-allied faction that until last month held the American soldier Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl hostage.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and ISMAIL KHAN
